source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: variations of hydride morphology can have a dramatic effect on the fracture behavior of Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: reoriented (radial-axial) hydrides and low test temperatures promote brittle crack extension with little or no stable crack growth

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: the crack path primarily follows the radial hydrides, which fracture by cleavage

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: the material between hydrides ruptures by microvoid coalescence

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: When the failure mode is ductile with significant stable crack growth, the crack path is not influenced by the presence of reoriented hydrides

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk5
evidence_span: the fracture surface exhibits ductile features

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: hydrogen concentrations in the range 60 to $8 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / k g }$

evidence_span: HCC values of about 0.5

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk6
evidence_span: hydrogen concentrations up to about $6 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / k g }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Delayed hydride crack velocities in $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb alloys with different thermomechanical treatments were measured

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Materials with higher strength have higher crack velocity

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: stepwise crack propagation occurred by smaller increments associated with a smaller zone of crack tip hydrides

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: An incubation period was required for the specimen to resume cracking after reducing the applied $\kappa$ to a level still significantly above the threshold stress intensity factor $K _ { \mathbb { H } }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The length of the incubation period depended on the amount of $K$ reduction, material strength, temperature, and the final $K$ in which cracking occurred

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Crack velocity increases with the amount of hydrogen in solution in the matrix

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Crack velocity increased as a function of the peak temperature reached in the initial cooldown thermal cycle

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: There is hysteresis in hydride solubility which results in different levels of hydrogen in solution depending upon the thermal history

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys have low solubility of hydrogen

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: zirconium hydride platelets are precipitated in the matrix when the hydrogen concentration exceeds the terminal solid solubility (TSS)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_008_chunk7
evidence_span: The presence of hydrides can lead to a reduction in ductility and fracture toughness when the hydrides are oriented in the radial-axial plane of the pressure tube
